frontmatter.title: CLI Application
frontmatter.description: Complete guide to using the Rediacc command-line interface for platform management

overview.heading: Overview
overview.text: The **Rediacc CLI** (`rdc`) is a command-line interface for managing all aspects of the Rediacc platform — authentication, infrastructure, repositories, queues, storage, and more.

installation.heading: Installation
installation.text: Download the latest binary for your platform from the [Rediacc releases page](https://www.rediacc.com) or install via your package manager:

globalOptions.heading: Global Options
globalOptions.intro: Every command supports these global flags:

errors.heading: Common Error Messages
errors.intro: When something goes wrong, the CLI provides clear error messages:

meanings.authRequired: You need to log in first
meanings.noActiveContext: No context is selected — create or switch to one
meanings.permissionDenied: Your account lacks the required permissions
meanings.machineRequired: Specify a machine with `--machine` or set a context default
meanings.teamRequired: Specify a team with `--team` or set a context default
meanings.regionRequired: Specify a region with `--region` or set a context default

outputFormats.heading: Output Formats
outputFormats.text: All list/get commands support multiple output formats via `--output`:
outputFormats.closing: This makes it easy to integrate Rediacc CLI into scripts, CI/CD pipelines, and automation workflows.

auth.tip: Your authentication token is stored locally in your context. Use `--save-as` to store credentials under a named context for multiple environments.

register.afterDescription: After registration, check your email for the activation code.

context.afterDescription: Contexts store connection details (API URL, credentials, default team/region/machine) so you can switch between environments quickly.

set.tip: Setting defaults means you don't need to pass `--team`, `--region`, or `--machine` with every command.

createLocal.afterDescription: In local mode you can add machines directly:

maintenance.warning: When maintenance mode is enabled, non-admin users cannot log in.

health.afterDescription: The health command outputs system metrics, container status, service stability, and storage information — useful for CI/CD pipeline checks.

testConnection.tip: Use `--save-known-hosts` to automatically persist the host key to the machine vault after a successful test.

promote.note: Promoting a fork separates it from its grand (parent) repository, making it independent.

queue.afterDescription: The queue system is at the heart of Rediacc's task execution. Every operation (deploy, backup, script execution) runs through the queue.

trace.tip: Use `--watch` to follow the task in real-time until it completes.
